projects.description: This project shows a quote randomly selected from an array. The quotes and background color will change every 10 seconds or will change with the click of a button.  The quotes will be authored either by Jane Austen, Charles Dickens, or Oscar Wilde.

For this project, I used JavaScript to paginate a long list of students and implement a search form to find students by name. The first screen shot shows a list of 54 students paginated 10 per page.  The second screen shot shows a search form that will filter students by name as you type in the search form field.

This is a form validation project, done without using HTML5 validation. Validation is done using jQuery and Regular Expression tests.  The first screen shot shows the message that will appear if the form is submitted without all fields being validated.  The second screen shot shows that the form will not allow registration for activities that occur at the same time -- when an activity is clicked, an activity ocurring at the same time will be disabled.  The third screen shot shows an error message that will occur if payment information is entered with no activity chosen.

For this object-oriented JavaScript project, I created a word game in which you need to guess the letters of a book title -- generally a well known American or English novel or play. You guess the letters by typing a letter on your keyboard or clicking the buttons on an on-screen keyboard. You have five tries - each incorrect guess will lose you one heart. In addition, I added a feature allowing you to see the author of the book, but it will cost one heart (try). On your fourth wrong guess, the option to see the author will disappear. After five wrong guesses, or if you correctly select all the letters in the title, you will see a screen indicating whether you won or lost, and displaying the book's title and author.

projects.project_name: Employee Directory using a Public API Request
projects.description: For this project, I requested, via the Fetch API interface, 12 employees from https://randomuser.me/. Employees are from Australia, United Kingdom, New Zealand, and the United States. If you click an employee, a modal will appear with further information about the employee. In addition, there is a search form field allowing you to filter employees by name. If you submit even a partial portion of the name (including just one letter), employees whose full names, first name, or last name match what has been entered will appear on the web page.

projects.project_name: Responsive Design with Movable Modal Box
projects.description: I was given a .jpg file with a design for the first part of T.S. Eliot's The Waste Land.  I created a responsive design, using SCSS and HTML5, to replicate the image as web page.  In addition, I added modal notecards, so that when you click on a footnote, a modal notecard will appear with TS Eliot's footnotes and other information, as appropriate.  Except on mobile devices, the modal boxes can be moved about the screen by clicking and holding down the mouse on the modal notecard.
